body:
Flow graph:

Server: 192.168.178.2
Desktop: 192.68.178.26

![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1926175/117354602-cdcada80-aeb1-11eb-8d12-b4a813691d1b.png)

Are you planning to look into it, tweak it/test it?

We use it out of the box and expect it to work, if it doesn't work as expected, I don't think it's worth having an issue here, as we are not going to fix it, and  it should probably be brought up with the quic people as I don't think we have any expertise here.

If you were to do that, I guess it would be best if you wrote a synthetic benchmark using their tools, just to rule out syncthing.
If it does seem that it's something that syncthing does, then we could look into it.

> Are you planning to look into it, tweak it/test it?

Sadly not a go developer but i'm happy to test.

> We use it out of the box and expect it to work, if it doesn't work as expected, I don't think it's worth having an issue here, as we are not going to fix it, and it should probably be brought up with the quic people as I don't think we have any expertise here.

quic-go is used by caddy and IPFS so I doubt it's supposed to be *that* slow. Maybe @marten-seemann can help here.

You could try compiling syncthing with the following diff applied and see if it makes it any better:
```diff
diff --git a/lib/connections/quic_listen.go b/lib/connections/quic_listen.go
index 5c90cfff4..0b6897659 100644
--- a/lib/connections/quic_listen.go
+++ b/lib/connections/quic_listen.go
@@ -89,19 +89,10 @@ func (t *quicListener) serve(ctx context.Context) error {
        }
        defer func() { _ = packetConn.Close() }()

-       svc, conn := stun.New(t.cfg, t, packetConn)
-       defer func() { _ = conn.Close() }()
-       wrapped := &stunConnQUICWrapper{
-               PacketConn: conn,
-               underlying: packetConn.(*net.UDPConn),
-       }
-
-       go svc.Serve(ctx)
-
-       registry.Register(t.uri.Scheme, wrapped)
-       defer registry.Unregister(t.uri.Scheme, wrapped)
+       registry.Register(t.uri.Scheme, packetConn)
+       defer registry.Unregister(t.uri.Scheme, packetConn)

-       listener, err := quic.Listen(wrapped, t.tlsCfg, quicConfig)
+       listener, err := quic.Listen(packetConn, t.tlsCfg, quicConfig)
        if err != nil {
                l.Infoln("Listen (BEP/quic):", err)
                return err
```

You can get a dev build of the change applied here: https://build.syncthing.net/viewLog.html?buildId=101803&buildTypeId=Syncthing_BuildCrossCompile&tab=artifacts

Suggest you don't run it on a fresh setup (don't just replace existing binaries and existing setup)

Edit: linked the cross compile build, but you can find the standard linux one by branch name.
Thanks. I will give it a shot tomorrow

[![Bountysource](https://api.bountysource.com/badge/issue?issue_id=98310943)](https://www.bountysource.com/issues/98310943-investigate-quic-performance)  
For investigating this, in case it helps.  
I wonder if there's a tool similar to `iperf` on top of `quic-go` to establish a baseline?

> You could try compiling syncthing with the following diff applied and see if it makes it any better:

I applied your patch on top of the v1.16.1 tag and compiled a binary for my Windows desktop. I changed the direction of my test and tried to sync a large 30GB file from my unpatched server to my desktop PC.

## Unpatched

![unpatched](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1926175/117537223-e2b58400-afff-11eb-9750-1f4092caa363.png)

Which was somewhat the expected result as 8MBit/s was also the cap when i tried syncing the other way around.

## Patched

![patched](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1926175/117537228-e812ce80-afff-11eb-8c67-0969be74de0f.png)

Yikes! From measly 8MBit/s to 250MBit/s ðŸš€ 

Note that I did not patch my server so the observed ~250MBit/s is probably not the maximum.
Does the packet flow look the same? (In terms of size distribution).
I captured both tests using Wireshark. I will upload the patched versions when i'm at my desktop

## Unpatch flow

![unpatched_flow](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1926175/117542561-6f207080-b019-11eb-987e-3ed0874e0f4b.png)

## Patched flow

![patched_flow](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1926175/117542569-747dbb00-b019-11eb-978e-97ff2fb16f2c.png)
Notice the delays in the unpatched flow

No idea how you are getting to those numbers. 

I wrote some synthetic benchmarks, which with TCP get to 1GB/s (which proves that the benchmark is not the bottleneck), with quic I can barely reach 25MB/s, with the patch applied.
Sorry, just realised your chart is bits not bytes, so I guess 25MB/s lines up with that.
Could you do another test. Once the connection is established, check the rate one way, and then on the same connection, the other way.

For the curious, some numbers:

Benchmark names mean:
```
<protocol>_<payload size>_<direction client->server server->client>
```

```
BenchmarkConnections/tcp_1024_cs-16                49586             21599 ns/op          47.41 MB/s          32 B/op          1 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/tcp_1024_sc-16                53096             22469 ns/op          45.57 MB/s          32 B/op          1 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/tcp_32768_cs-16               24948             48140 ns/op         680.68 MB/s          68 B/op          2 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/tcp_32768_sc-16               24489             48062 ns/op         681.78 MB/s          67 B/op          2 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/tcp_1048576_cs-16              1188           1015151 ns/op        1032.93 MB/s        2159 B/op         63 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/tcp_1048576_sc-16              1212           1014027 ns/op        1034.07 MB/s        2158 B/op         63 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/tcp_4194304_cs-16               286           4174830 ns/op        1004.66 MB/s        8569 B/op        252 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/tcp_4194304_sc-16               289           4148790 ns/op        1010.97 MB/s        8655 B/op        254 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/quic_1024_cs-16                7999            352419 ns/op           2.91 MB/s        2368 B/op         43 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/quic_1024_sc-16                4058            268359 ns/op           3.82 MB/s        2378 B/op         43 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/quic_32768_cs-16                100          24449956 ns/op           1.34 MB/s       65131 B/op       1221 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/quic_32768_sc-16                100          54259996 ns/op           0.60 MB/s       59483 B/op       1126 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/quic_1048576_cs-16                2        1207999700 ns/op           0.87 MB/s     1960320 B/op      37052 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/quic_1048576_sc-16                1        1554998800 ns/op           0.67 MB/s     1919848 B/op      36025 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/quic_4194304_cs-16                1        1691587100 ns/op           2.48 MB/s     8666040 B/op     160171 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/quic_4194304_sc-16                1        4796513600 ns/op           0.87 MB/s     7889896 B/op     149974 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/relay_1024_cs-16              25156             46828 ns/op          21.87 MB/s          32 B/op          1 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/relay_1024_sc-16              25156             47424 ns/op          21.59 MB/s          32 B/op          1 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/relay_32768_cs-16             14167             83786 ns/op         391.09 MB/s          71 B/op          2 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/relay_32768_sc-16             14268             93286 ns/op         351.27 MB/s          73 B/op          2 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/relay_1048576_cs-16            1333           1000000 ns/op        1048.58 MB/s         973 B/op         27 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/relay_1048576_sc-16            1212           1615511 ns/op         649.07 MB/s        1807 B/op         52 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/relay_4194304_cs-16             276           4543487 ns/op         923.15 MB/s        7207 B/op        204 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/relay_4194304_sc-16             387           4509048 ns/op         930.20 MB/s        7406 B/op        219 allocs/op
```
This is with the stun wrapper in place. 

If we remove the stun wrapper we get:
```
BenchmarkConnections/quic_1024_cs-16               17569             67790 ns/op          15.11 MB/s        2296 B/op         41 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/quic_1024_sc-16                5001            218756 ns/op           4.68 MB/s        2252 B/op         40 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/quic_32768_cs-16                874           1458813 ns/op          22.46 MB/s       58001 B/op       1059 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/quic_32768_sc-16                220           9204545 ns/op           3.56 MB/s       55350 B/op       1033 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/quic_1048576_cs-16               30          47133390 ns/op          22.25 MB/s     1955835 B/op      28559 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/quic_1048576_sc-16               13         113054200 ns/op           9.27 MB/s     2222731 B/op      34754 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/quic_4194304_cs-16                8         150874950 ns/op          27.80 MB/s     8106373 B/op     130010 allocs/op
BenchmarkConnections/quic_4194304_sc-16                7         646571757 ns/op           6.49 MB/s     7057612 B/op     131083 allocs/op
```

Interesting how quic performs a lot worse in one of the directions.
On the bright side, relays (atleast while running locally), don't seem to be a bottleneck.
I guess next steps is to understand why the stun glue is a bottleneck.

> Interesting how quic performs a lot worse in one of the directions.

On which platforms did you run your tests? You should keep an eye on the UDP buffer errors (e.g using `netstat -naus`) as the receive buffer size seems to have a major impact: https://github.com/lucas-clemente/quic-go/issues/2586#issuecomment-639247615

One other theory is that quic might get thrown off by small writes. Our TCP connections explicitly disable TCP_NODELAY and might therefore handle this more gracefully. See https://forum.syncthing.net/t/is-there-a-specific-reason-why-syncthing-explicitly-turns-off-tcp-nodelay/16363

If I may chime in here, it's important that the `net.PacketConn` you pass to quic-go allow interface assertions the functions of a `net.UDPConn`. For example, see https://github.com/lucas-clemente/quic-go/blob/8d62ebffae4678665947262265037d32bee914e6/packet_handler_map.go#L84-L111.

If you wrap a `net.UDPConn`, and don't expose `SetReadBuffer` explicitly, quic-go won't be able to call that function.

Hi Marten, thanks for chiming in ;)

We are aware of that and have a wrapper that exposes that function from the underlying connection:  
https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/main/lib/connections/quic_listen.go#L228
https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/main/lib/connections/quic_listen.go#L94

That looks correct. You might want to consider exposing the function of the [`quic.OOBCapableConn`](https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/lucas-clemente/quic-go#OOBCapablePacketConn) as well, but that's most likely unrelated to your problem here.

issue.title: lib/connections: Add more methods to the quic conn wrapper

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

milestone.title: v1.17.0
milestone.description: This release deprecates TLS 1.2 for sync connections; other side should be Syncthing 1.3.0 or newer, or see [insecureAllowOldTLSVersions](https://docs.syncthing.net/advanced/option-insecure-allow-old-tls-versions.html).

issue.body: Marten from the quic project mentioned a few more methods required by quic from the underlying connection in https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/7636#issuecomment-835482900

body: All the benchmarks were run on my Windows workstation.
Can you try running them on Linux? Timer resolution on Windows is really poor, which might harm performance in unpredictable ways.
Sure, I'll try that tomorrow.
Is the difference in performance based on direction expected? Or is this somewhat surprising?
